Award.AwardTitle: MIRT: Stressed Polymers - Exploiting Tension in Soft Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
MIRT: Stressed Polymers - Exploiting Tension in Soft Matter

Mechanical stress is integral to all living and many synthetic systems, from cells and muscles to catalysts and elastomers. It underpins the most common types of actions, responses, and stimuli. The general goal of this MIRT is to develop new principles in soft materials design, ones wherein mechanical stress in materials is generated, managed, and harvested by molecular engineering. One specific goal is to explore the interplay between the stress state of macroscopic materials and the chemistry of specific, addressable bonds within them. Novel materials functions will be made possible through controlled self-generation of bond tension and the intelligent processing of both internal and external stress into activation of specific chemical bonds. The other goal is to design multifunctional polymer particles and substrates that autonomously change their shape, surface structure, mechanical, and optical properties. The Team will further exploit its know-how in the fabrication of nanostructured objects with unprecedented fidelity and uniformity to prepare the next generation of shape-memory particles and substrates, designed to store mechanical stress and focus it at the molecular level via controlled strain release. The outlined goals will be achieved through interdisciplinary research, international collaboration, and interactive teamwork of synthetic chemists, experimental and theoretical physicist, and engineers across three campuses of the University of North Carolina, Carnegie Mellon University, and Duke University.

This interdisciplinary project will provide considerable opportunity for innovation and technology transfer, integrating science into education, and broadening participation of underrepresented groups. Increasing diversity for enhanced research innovation and collaboration is an integral dimension of the UNC MIRT: diversity in race and gender will complement the diversity of thoughts, skills, backgrounds, and disciplines. The education program includes four key constituents: 1) Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates focused on minorities and women from neighboring Historically Black Colleges and Universities and women's colleges with research, education, and social events; 2) Year round mentoring for undergraduate and high school students with active participation in the full cycle of MIRT research activities; 3) Graduate education with research support, travel awards and a new personal development program focused on innovation, diversity, and communication skills; 4) Junior researcher engagement for 7th-12th graders with activities to increase their exposure to, and enthusiasm and interest in, innovative science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal is to develop new principles in soft materials design where mechanical stress is generated, managed, and harvested by molecular engineering. This MIRT has explored the physical nature and practical implications of the inherent stress on different length scales ranging from individual covalent bonds and macromolecules to materials and discrete objects. The research led to novel multifunctional polymer particles and substrates that autonomously change their shape, surface structure, mechanical and optical properties. These novel materials have potential applications in, among other areas, soft robotics, catalysis, and medical therapy.

Intellectual Merit. On the molecular scale, the design guidelines of strained macromolecules along with physical principles of tension management, including generation, amplification, and focusing tension at specific chemical bonds were outlined. Several ground-breaking discoveries have been made. For example, it has been shown that chemical bonds in extended polymer brushes are actually compressed. This counterintuitive behavior is attributed to a dual effect of chain extension and density increase upon increasing grafting density. The next milestone in tension management was reached by introducing branched architectures that allowed not only amplification of tension but also its focusing to specific bonds. This resulted in physically patterned molecules possessing uniform chemical composition and heterogeneous electronic structure. Moreover, significant alterations of the intramolecular stress were demonstrated due to the effect of geometrical confinement. These findings highlight interesting opportunities for the development of mechanically activated photoresists, catalysts, and chromophores.

On a macroscopic scale, a synergistic effect was achieved by combining strained molecular architectures and targeted chemical compositions to design superlubricating coatings. Polyzwitterionic bottlebrushes tethered to a solid substrate have demonstrated a friction coefficient as low as that of pure water and exceeding the performance of natural lubricin under similar conditions.  Another significant breakthrough includes reversible transformation between two programmable shapes. This reversible shapeshifting is neither mechanically nor structurally constrained, thereby allowing for multiple switching between encoded shapes without applying any external force. Feasible practical applications have been highlighted by shifting wetting properties, optical reflectivity, and flow rate. A robotic gripper allowing multiple translocation of objects has been developed.

Our achievements on the molecular and macroscopic length scales have been integrated to design ultra-tough hydrogels with time-programmable shape alterations. These materials displayed a unique combination of mechanical properties (high rigidity, extensibility, and strength) that are on par with rigid living tissue. The time programming was realized through incorporation of dynamic bonds with controlled and adjustable life time. These materials display the unique ability to change their physical properties not in response to an external trigger, but simply as a function of time. This development may be extremely useful in systems where external stimuli are neither permissible nor effective. These include human body, subsurface environment and space missions. Biomedical applications are particularly intriguing as they allow deployment of an implant followed by its shape transformation inside a human body without any external and frequently invasive stimulation.

Broader Impact. The model of self-strained macromolecular systems has been well-received in the biophysical community leading to a new mechanism of segregation of chromosomes during mitosis. A new paradigm of the so-called primordial segregation machine was developed based on self-organization of pericentric chromatin into an inherently strained bottlebrush configuration, which generates a tensile force sufficient to release nucleosomes proximal to the spindle axis. On a different front, the development of time-programmable materials may impact other disciplines of science and engineering including biomedical engineering, geophysics, and space exploration. Practical applications include new designs for any implanted devices that need to be inserted through small incisions and then occupy a larger size inside the body. Drug-release systems offer another frontier. A device might be programmed to dispense a medication, or a series of medications, over weeks or months.

Overall, this project has fostered collaborative infrastructure for interdisciplinary research on campus through integration of four Departments: Chemistry, Physics, Applied Mathematics, and Biomedical Engineering. In addition, both strategic and productive collaborations were established with different US universities (UC Berkeley, UCSB, Harvard, Colorado School of Mines, UAkron, Penn State, UConn, Stanford), national laboratories (Sandia, BNL, ONR), international labs (EPFL, CNRS, TUE, UBonn, UToronto, ESPCI), and industry (Halliburton, Eastman, Bridgestone, and Carbon-3D). In this environment, a start-up company has been established, two patents have been filed, and students received international and industrial research experience.

The REU program has a unique focus on supporting underrepresented groups by recruiting students through the infrastructure of neighboring HBCU’s and providing full-scale research mentorship both during Summer and Academic Year. The URG focus of the REU program has been closely integrated with the overall emphasis of this MIRT on promoting research career of female graduate students that culminated in several significant awards, fellowships, and conference recognitions. The individual success of the MIRT female students combined with their dedicated mentorship of the REU students proved a role-model environment for nurturing a new generation of researchers.
